blocks.text: What the City of Toronto does

After you take away the administrative portion of city work, the rest is divided more or less evenly between general city services, and resident support services. The budget and audited financial statements paint slightly different, but similar pictures.
The 2017 budget is shown in the chart. We've learned that budget documents aren't very accurate, but they give a good general idea of what's going on.
General City Services ($4.9B, 24,000 people) consists of Transportation (Roads & TTC), Utilities (Water and Waste), and City Commons (Parks, Library, and City-owned destinations)

Resident Support Services ($4.7B, 21,000 people) consists of Human Services (income, housing, and child support), Protective Services (police, fire, and paramedics), and Health Services (Public Health & Long Term Care)
Administrative Services ($2.7B, 6,500 people) is what you would normally think of as City Hall work. It also includes Capital Account (financing) activities.
For detailed information, see our explorer.
Toronto also budgets about $3B in capital projects each year, although it only manages to implement about 2/3 of that. The largest spender is the TTC.
